bio:treatment.discussion: According to L. G. Hickok (1977), Ceratopteris richardii is diploid. Morphologically, specimens from the United States are difficult to distinguish from tetraploid C . thalictroides . The primary characteristic distinguishing C . richardii is its 16-spored sporangia. Herbarium specimens with 16-spored sporangia from the West Indies and Latin America have variable morphology ranging from that of C . pteridoides to that of C . thalictroides (R. M. Lloyd 1974, fig. 6). Some specimens have both 16- and 32-spored sporangia. This suggests multiple origins for C . richardii . Because reproductive isolation is incomplete among the diploid taxa, and highly fertile F 2 segregates of various morphologic types occur, further work is needed to determine the nature, origin, and distinctness of C . richardii .
